Phylogenetic Distances: The UniFrac Family

Source: R/bdiv_phylo.r
bdiv_phylo.Rd

The UniFrac family of metrics represents a major conceptual advance for microbial ecology, integrating phylogenetic information directly into the calculation of beta diversity. All UniFrac metrics operate on a phylogenetic tree that includes all taxa observed across the samples being compared. The fundamental principle is to measure the total branch length of the tree that is unique to each community, providing a measure of divergent evolution.

Usage

unweighted_unifrac(counts, tree = NULL, pairs = NULL, cpus = n_cpus())

weighted_unifrac(counts, tree = NULL, pairs = NULL, cpus = n_cpus())

normalized_unifrac(counts, tree = NULL, pairs = NULL, cpus = n_cpus())

generalized_unifrac(
  counts,
  tree = NULL,
  alpha = 0.5,
  pairs = NULL,
  cpus = n_cpus()
)

variance_adjusted_unifrac(counts, tree = NULL, pairs = NULL, cpus = n_cpus())

Arguments

counts

A numeric matrix of count data where each column is a sample, and each row is a feature. Any object coercible with as.matrix() can be given here, as well as phyloseq, rbiom, SummarizedExperiment, and TreeSummarizedExperiment objects.

tree

A phylo-class object representing the phylogenetic tree for the OTUs in counts. The OTU identifiers given by colnames(counts) must be present in tree. Can be omitted if a tree is embedded with the counts object or as attr(counts, 'tree').

pairs

Which combinations of samples should distances be calculated for? The default value (NULL) calculates all-vs-all. Provide a numeric or logical vector specifying positions in the distance matrix to calculate. See examples.

cpus

How many parallel processing threads should be used. The default, n_cpus(), will use all logical CPU cores.

alpha

How much weight to give to relative abundances; a value between 0 and 1, inclusive. Setting alpha=1 is equivalent to normalized_unifrac().

Value

A dist object.

Details

Unweighted and Weighted UniFrac

  • The original Unweighted UniFrac is a qualitative metric. It calculates the fraction of the total branch length in the tree that leads to descendants from only one of the two communities, but not both. Because it operates on presence/absence, it is highly sensitive to changes in rare lineages. The appearance or disappearance of a taxon that represents a deep, unique branch on the tree will result in a large UniFrac distance.

  • Weighted UniFrac is the quantitative counterpart. It weights the branch lengths in the tree by the difference in the proportion of sequences that descend from that branch in each community. This makes it much more sensitive to changes in the abundance of dominant lineages. A small change in a very abundant clade will have a larger impact on the distance than the complete loss of a rare clade.

  • The Normalized Weighted UniFrac is a simple modification that scales the distance to fall between 0 and 1, facilitating comparisons.

Advanced UniFrac Variants: Generalized and Variance-Adjusted

The stark difference in sensitivity between unweighted (rare lineages) and weighted (abundant lineages) UniFrac led to the development of more advanced versions to capture a wider range of biological changes.

  • Generalized UniFrac (GUniFrac) was developed to bridge this gap. It introduces a parameter, \(\alpha\), that tunes the weight given to abundant lineages. When \(\alpha\)=0, GUniFrac is similar to Unweighted UniFrac; when \(\alpha\)=1, it is similar to Weighted UniFrac. By using an intermediate value, such as the recommended \(\alpha\)=0.5, GUniFrac can effectively detect changes in moderately abundant lineages that might be missed by the other two methods, making it a more robust and powerful tool overall.

  • Variance-Adjusted Weighted UniFrac (VAW-UniFrac) addresses a statistical limitation of the original Weighted UniFrac. It recognizes that the observed abundances are estimates subject to sampling variation. VAW-UniFrac adjusts the weight on each branch by its variance, which can increase the statistical power to detect genuine differences between communities, especially when sample sizes are uneven.

Calculation

Given \(n\) branches with lengths \(L\) and a pair of samples' abundances (\(A\) and \(B\)) on each of those branches:

Unweighted UniFrac unweighted_unifrac()

$$D_{unweighted} = \displaystyle \frac{\sum_{i} L_i(|A_i - B_i|)}{\sum_{i} L_i(max(A_i,B_i))}$$

In \(D_{unweighted}\), abundances \(A\) and \(B\) are coded as 1 or 0 to indicate their presence or absence, respectively, on each branch.

Weighted UniFrac weighted_unifrac()

$$D_{weighted} = \displaystyle \sum_{i} L_i|\frac{A_i}{A_T} - \frac{B_i}{B_T}|$$

Normalized Weighted UniFrac normalized_unifrac()

$$D_{normalized} = \displaystyle \frac{\sum_{i} L_i|\frac{A_i}{A_T} - \frac{B_i}{B_T}|}{\sum_{i} L_i(\frac{A_i}{A_T} + \frac{B_i}{B_T})}$$

Generalized UniFrac generalized_unifrac()

$$D_{generalized} = \displaystyle \frac{\sum_{i} L_i(\frac{A_i}{A_T} + \frac{B_i}{B_T})^{\alpha}|\displaystyle \frac{\frac{A_i}{A_T} - \frac{B_i}{B_T}}{\frac{A_i}{A_T} + \frac{B_i}{B_T}} |}{\sum_{i} L_i(\frac{A_i}{A_T} + \frac{B_i}{B_T})^{\alpha}}$$

Variance-Adjusted Weighted UniFrac variance_adjusted_unifrac()

$$D_{varAdjusted} = \displaystyle \frac{\sum_{i} L_i\displaystyle \frac{|\frac{A_i}{A_T} - \frac{B_i}{B_T}|}{\sqrt{(A_i + B_i)(A_T + B_T - A_i - B_i)}} }{\sum_{i} L_i\displaystyle \frac{\frac{A_i}{A_T} + \frac{B_i}{B_T}}{\sqrt{(A_i + B_i)(A_T + B_T - A_i - B_i)}} }$$

See vignette('unifrac') for details and a worked example.

References

Lozupone C, Knight R (2005). UniFrac: A new phylogenetic method for comparing microbial communities. Applied and Environmental Microbiology, 71(12). doi:10.1128/AEM.71.12.8228-8235.2005

Lozupone CA, Hamady M, Kelley ST, Knight R (2007). Quantitative and Qualitative \(\beta\) Diversity Measures Lead to Different Insights into Factors That Structure Microbial Communities. Applied and Environmental Microbiology, 73(5). doi:10.1128/AEM.01996-06

Chen J, Bittinger K, Charlson ES, Hoffmann C, Lewis J, Wu GD, Collman RG, Bushman FD, Li H (2012). Associating microbiome composition with environmental covariates using generalized UniFrac distances. Bioinformatics, 28(16). doi:10.1093/bioinformatics/bts342

Chang Q, Luan Y, Sun F (2011). Variance adjusted weighted UniFrac: a powerful beta diversity measure for comparing communities based on phylogeny. BMC Bioinformatics, 12. doi:10.1186/1471-2105-12-118

Examples

    # Example counts matrix
    ex_counts
#>                   Saliva Gums Nose Stool
#> Streptococcus        162  793   22     1
#> Bacteroides            2    4    2   611
#> Corynebacterium        0    0  498     1
#> Haemophilus          180   87    2     1
#> Propionibacterium      1    1  251     0
#> Staphylococcus         0    1  236     1
    
    unweighted_unifrac(ex_counts, tree = ex_tree)
#>           Saliva       Gums       Nose
#> Gums  0.05759162                      
#> Nose  0.16279070 0.11162791           
#> Stool 0.22325581 0.17209302 0.06046512
    
    weighted_unifrac(ex_counts, tree = ex_tree)
#>          Saliva      Gums      Nose
#> Gums   37.08021                    
#> Nose   67.00360  55.56710          
#> Stool 110.25564 109.96250 110.14056
    
    normalized_unifrac(ex_counts, tree = ex_tree)
#>          Saliva      Gums      Nose
#> Gums  0.4343436                    
#> Nose  0.7891160 0.6714592          
#> Stool 0.9707293 0.9868636 0.9925679
    
    generalized_unifrac(ex_counts, tree = ex_tree)
#>          Saliva      Gums      Nose
#> Gums  0.4471644                    
#> Nose  0.8215129 0.7607876          
#> Stool 0.9727827 0.9784242 0.9730332
    
    variance_adjusted_unifrac(ex_counts, tree = ex_tree)
#>          Saliva      Gums      Nose
#> Gums  0.4242631                    
#> Nose  0.7753369 0.5565010          
#> Stool 0.9655749 0.9807634 0.9785147
    
    # Only calculate distances for A vs all.
    unweighted_unifrac(ex_counts, tree = ex_tree, pairs = 1:3)
#>           Saliva       Gums       Nose
#> Gums  0.05759162                      
#> Nose  0.16279070         NA           
#> Stool 0.22325581         NA         NA
